sec.title: Objectives
sec.p: To investigate whether seafarers in Norway who were declared unfit for service at sea or received a time-limited health certificate had a higher risk of acute somatic hospital admissions compared with those who received a full health certificate.

sec.title: Design
sec.p: Registry-based cohort study.

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: Seafarers in Norway who presented to a seafarer’s doctor to obtain a health certificate between 2018 and 2019, as required for work aboard Norwegian vessels. The study was conducted within Norway’s publicly funded healthcare system.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Norwegian seafarers aged 18–70 years who underwent medical examinations (n=43 758), including n=5452 females (12.5%).

sec.title: Outcome measures
sec.p: Acute somatic hospital admission within 2 years of medical examination. HRs were estimated using Cox regression models in two separate time periods (0–3 months and 3–24 months), with adjustment for possible confounding from age, gender, level of education and centrality of residence (proximity to healthcare services).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The crude risk of acute somatic hospital admissions was higher for individuals who received a declaration of unfitness, as compared with those who received a full health certificate, in both follow-up periods: 0–3 months (HR=5.13, 95% CI: 3.27 to 8.04) and 3–24 months (HR=2.63, 95% CI: 2.07 to 3.34). Similarly, those with time-limited health certificates had a higher risk in both periods: 0–3 months (HR=2.02, 95% CI: 1.39 to 2.93) and 3–24 months (HR=2.45, 95% CI: 2.15 to 2.79). Adjustment of the analyses for socio-demographic factors did not change the effect estimates substantially.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: These findings highlight the importance of comprehensive and continuous health assessments to help prevent adverse health outcomes and ensure safety at sea, particularly among vulnerable subgroups of seafarers.

caption.title: STRENGTHS AND LIMITATIONS OF THIS STUDY

list-item.p: The use of linked, national registry data provided an objective measure of healthcare utilisation.
Norway’s universal healthcare system and national hospital registry enabled a complete, population-wide overview.
The lack of data on hospital admissions outside Norway may lead to underestimation of hospitalisation rates among seafarers working abroad for extended periods.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Seafaring is crucial for global transportation, shipping goods across oceans and resupplying the offshore industries. Seafarers often spend extended periods at sea, living and working away from home for long stretches. Seafarers face demanding working conditions and hazardous environment, which can negatively impact their health.1 Research indicates that the risk of ill health and premature death is significantly higher among seafarers compared with workers on land.2 3

Ill health among seafarers can severely impair their ability to perform essential duties, posing risks to both their own safety and that of their crew. Medical emergencies at sea can lead to operational disruptions and increased strain on fellow crew members. In severe cases, emergency evacuations may be required, often complicated by unpredictable weather conditions and remote maritime locations. The nature of ill health of seafarers has been sparsely researched. The few existing studies indicate that seafarers suffer from a wide range of health issues, including communicable diseases, injuries and the exacerbation of pre-existing medical conditions.410

In Norway, seafarers are required to hold a valid health certificate to work aboard ships.11 Despite a limited evidence base, the medical selection of seafarers has long been used to identify individuals at elevated risk of health-related events, including those with conditions such as cardiovascular disease, epilepsy and mental health issues.4 This process aims to ensure that only those who are medically fit are cleared for work at sea. Health certificates are issued by recognised seafarer’s doctors and include full health certificates with a maximum validity period of 2 years, time-limited or restricted health certificates and declarations of unfitness. Seafarer’s doctors assess both pre-existing conditions and current health status to determine medical fitness, as these factors may contribute to acute medical incidents at sea.

The aim of this study was to assess whether the medical selection of seafarers could predict the risk of acute somatic hospital admissions during the 2-year period following the medical examination. Specifically, we investigated whether seafarers declared unfit for service at sea or issued a time-limited health certificate in Norway had a higher risk of acute somatic hospital admissions compared with those who received a full health certificate.

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p: This study followed the Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in Epidemiology cohort reporting guidelines.12

sec.title: Study design and population
sec.p: This registry-based study includes Norwegian seafarers who presented themselves to a seafarer’s doctor in Norway between 2018 and 2019, to acquire a health certificate. The study population was obtained from the Norwegian Maritime Authority (NMA) and included seafarers aged 18 to 70 years, reflecting the normal working age in Norway (n=43 782). A total of 24 seafarers were excluded from the study due to the issuance of an invalid health certificate with validity of zero days.

The study population was divided into three categories: Group 1, ‘full health certificate’ included seafarers who received a health certificate with a validity period of more than 1 year (n=41 599); Group 2, ‘time-limited health certificate’ included seafarers who received a health certificate restricted to 1 year or less (n=1706); and Group 3 included seafarers who received a declaration of unfitness (n=453) (figure 1).

sec.title: Data sources and variables
sec.p: Data obtained from the NMA included information on health certificates (full health certificate or time-limited), declaration of unfitness, date of issue, expiry date and information on maritime certificates of competency (table 1).

sec.p: Data from the NMA was linked to hospital admission data from the Norwegian Patient Registry (NPR), using each individual’s unique Norwegian identification number. Only admissions to somatic institutions or departments were included and are referred to as acute somatic hospital admissions. Variables included diagnosis, urgency of admission and date/time of admission.

Socio-demographic variables were obtained from Statistics Norway and included time of birth and death (month and year), gender, level of education and centrality index of residence. The level of education was divided into three categories: primary school or no registered education, upper secondary school and higher education. The centrality index of residence reflects proximity and access to public healthcare, where group 1 represents the most central and group 6 represents the least central (table 1). The reference date for the centrality index was 1 January 2021.

sec.title: Statistics
sec.p: In order to assess the data, we used survival analysis, defining the first acute hospital admission within 2 years following the seafarer’s medical examination as the event of interest. Seafarers who did not experience an acute hospital admission were censored at the date of death or at the end of the 2-year follow-up period.

Differences in the risk of acute hospital admissions among the three groups of seafarers (full health certificate, time-limited health certificate and declaration of unfitness) were assessed in Cox regression models. The seafarers who received a full health certificate were used as the reference group. Risk comparison estimates, expressed as HRs, were reported both with and without adjustment for potential confounders, including age at the time of declaration, gender, level of education (primary school or no registered education, upper secondary school and higher education) and centrality of residence. Centrality was based on index categories 1–6, with an additional category for individuals who were alive but lacked a registered residence in Norway as of the reference date (1 January 2021). Individuals who had died prior to this date were excluded from the adjusted analyses through listwise deletion, affecting a total of 97 individuals. To satisfy the proportional hazards assumption, Cox regression analyses were performed in two separate time periods: 0 to 3 months and 3 to 24 months following the medical examination. The 2-year cumulative incidence of acute somatic hospital admissions was calculated as one minus the Kaplan–Meier estimate (1 KM). P values less than 0.05 were considered statistically significant.
The data were analysed using the Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (SPSS) version 29, developed by SPSS Inc. in Chicago, IL, USA, and STATA version 18.
This study has been approved by the Regional Committee for Medical and Health Research Ethics of Western Norway (REK no. 185080).

sec.title: Patient and public involvement
sec.p: No patients were involved.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A total of 43 758 seafarers, including 5452 females (12.5%), participated in this study. Socio-demographic variables of the study population are presented in table 1.

The 2-year cumulative incidence of acute somatic hospital admissions for seafarers issued with a declaration of unfitness was 19.7% (95% CI: 16.3% to 23.6%), compared with 16.4% (95% CI: 14.7% to 18.2%) for those who received a time-limited health certificate, and 7.2% (95% CI: 7.0% to 7.5%) for seafarers who received a full health certificate (figure 2).

caption.title: 2-year cumulative proportion of acute somatic hospital admissions after presenting to a seafarer’s doctor for the groups of seafarers.

sec.p: The crude risk of acute somatic hospital admissions was more than twice as high for seafarers who received a time-limited health certificate, as compared with those who received a full health certificate, in both follow-up periods 0–3 months (HR=2.02, 95% CI: 1.39 to 2.93) and 3–24 months (HR=2.45, 95% CI: 2.15 to 2.79). This was also the case for seafarers declared unfit when isolating the follow-up period from 3 to 24 months after presenting to a seafarer’s doctor (HR=2.63, 95% CI: 2.07 to 3.34), with a more than fivefold increase in risk during the first 3 months (HR=5.13, 95% CI: 3.27 to 8.04). Adjustment for possible confounding from age, gender, level of education and centrality of residence did not substantially alter our findings (online supplemental table 1).

In our primary analysis, injuries were included as a cause of acute somatic admissions, as we did not differentiate between various diagnoses. We conducted two sensitivity analyses. In the first, we excluded injuries as an event of interest (figure 3). In the second, to focus on active seafarers, we excluded those who had received only one full health certificate during the period 2016 to 2021 (n=6260). Both sensitivity analyses produced results that were similar to our main analyses or showed more pronounced effect estimates (online supplemental tables 2 and 3).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We found a significantly higher risk of acute somatic hospital admissions among seafarers who were declared unfit and seafarers who received a time-limited health certificate, compared with those who received a full health certificate.

The assessment of medical fitness to work at sea is a vital component of maritime risk management. It ensures that individuals with pre-existing health conditions, which may worsen or pose a risk to others while at sea, are either restricted to duties that mitigate potential hazards or, in certain cases, excluded from seafaring. Our results align with previous research highlighting the importance of reliable medical evaluations in identifying individuals unsuitable for seafaring duties.4 The physical well-being of seafarers is essential not only for their own health but also for the safety of the entire crew, as medical emergencies at sea can increase workload and jeopardise operational stability.13

In our study, seafarers who received time-limited health certificates, or a declaration of unfitness, were, on average, older and had lower educational levels than those who received full health certificates. Access to healthcare services was also considered, as studies indicate that distance and travel time can significantly affect healthcare utilisation. Additionally, both acute and chronic diseases, including cancer, diabetes and heart disease, are more prevalent in rural and remote populations.14 Socio-demographic factors may influence the risk of hospitalisation in several ways. Age is a well-established risk factor for increased disease burden.15 Lower educational levels are associated with reduced engagement in preventive healthcare.16

The elevated risk of acute admissions was most pronounced within the first 3 months for seafarers declared to be unfit. This finding suggests that these individuals may have had pre-existing conditions that were first identified during their medical examination, leading to a prompt increase in hospital admissions. This pattern is consistent with findings from general medical practice, where medical screenings often lead to an increase in unplanned hospital admissions due to previously undetected or unmanaged conditions.17

Seafarers who received time-limited health certificates exhibited long-term hospitalisation rates comparable to those declared unfit. This finding may be particularly relevant to seafarers’ doctors when deciding whether to issue a time-limited certificate for a short duration or declare a seafarer unfit, especially in borderline cases.

sec.title: Strengths and limitations
sec.p: To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study to evaluate the admission rates of seafarers in the 2-year period following a seafarer doctor’s assessment. The study provides a comprehensive analysis of a large population of seafarers and current medical selection practices within the maritime industry. Our findings highlight the critical role of seafarer doctors in identifying individuals at elevated risk for acute medical events and thereby help to prevent health-related emergencies that could endanger both individual well-being and operational safety at sea.

The use of Norwegian health registries provides comprehensive and reliable information on all hospital admissions across both public and private healthcare facilities, minimising the risk of information bias.

The ability to adjust for key potential confounders, such as age, gender, educational level and centrality of residence, strengthens the validity of the findings by accounting for risk factors associated with hospitalisation. Furthermore, following seafarers over a 2-year period after their medical assessment allows an evaluation of the predictive value of seafarer medical examinations in identifying individuals at risk of acute health events.

This study does not include data on hospital admissions occurring outside Norway, as the NPR only records hospitalisations within Norway. This limitation may have led to an underestimation of the overall hospitalisation rate, particularly for seafarers who spend extended periods working abroad. The main objectives of the NPR are to facilitate administration, management, financing and quality assurance of the specialist health services.18 The purpose of health registries may influence the quality of reporting.

The study includes a 2-year follow-up period, which limits the ability to assess long-term health outcomes in the seafarer population. Another limitation is the lack of data on the specific reasons for health certificate denial or the issuance of time-limited certificates. Additionally, the available data only distinguish between time-limited and non-time-limited certificates, without information on other potential restrictions, such as limitations on areas of operation.

While our findings primarily reflect the Norwegian maritime workforce, the medical selection processes for seafarers worldwide are governed by the International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping for Seafarers,19 resulting in the applicability of our findings to seafarers internationally. However, differences in healthcare infrastructure, access to medical services and the prevalence of specific health conditions across countries could potentially limit the generalisability of these findings. Future research incorporating international data on hospital admissions and healthcare access could further strengthen these findings and provide a more comprehensive perspective on the health outcomes of seafarers globally.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In conclusion, this study finds that seafarers who receive a declaration of unfitness, as well as those who receive time-limited health certificates, face a significantly higher risk of acute hospital admissions compared with seafarers who receive full health certificates. Our findings highlight the importance of comprehensive and continuous health assessments for seafarers to prevent adverse health outcomes, particularly among vulnerable subgroups.
